holidays.name: Chop Suey Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the classic American-Chinese dish that never fails to bring together a mix of crunchy veggies, tender meat, and savory sauce in a tasty medley.
holidays.origin: Chop Suey became popular in the United States in the late 19th century as Chinese immigrants adapted their cuisine to American tastes, creating a dish that means "assorted pieces."
holidays.funFact: Despite popular belief, chop suey was invented in America, not China, making it a true fusion cuisine success story!

holidays.name: More Herbs, Less Salt Day
holidays.description: Promoting healthier eating habits by encouraging people to flavor food with fresh herbs instead of excess salt.
holidays.origin: Created by nutritionists and health organizations to raise awareness about reducing sodium intake and the benefits of herbs in cooking.
holidays.funFact: Replacing just one teaspoon of salt with herbs can save about 2,300 mg of sodium â€“ nearly a full day's recommended limit!

holidays.name: National Bow Tie Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration of the dapper neckwear that adds personality and flair to any outfit.
holidays.origin: The bow tie has been a symbol of individuality and style since the 19th century, and this day honors those who choose to wear it proudly.
holidays.funFact: Winston Churchill was famously photographed sporting a bow tie, solidifying it as a mark of distinguished style.

holidays.name: Be Loud! Day
holidays.description: A fun, energetic day dedicated to being expressive, vocal, and not afraid to make some noise!
holidays.origin: A modern unofficial celebration encouraging people to break out of their shells and shout their enthusiasm about life.
holidays.funFact: Be Loud! Day is a favorite among musicians, activists, and anyone who loves to make their voice heard.
